info.name: Egyptian Epochs
info.description: Can your Egyptian dynasty stand the test of time?
info.similarAwards:
2016 Juego del Año Recommended
2000 International Gamers Awards - General Strategy; Multi-player Nominee
1999 Meeples' Choice Award
info.ruleText:
Objective
Over the course of three epochs (rounds), acquire tiles at auction through clever use of your coins. A scoring phase takes place at the end of each epoch. After the conclusion and scoring phase of the third epoch, the game ends and the high-scoring player wins.

Scoring
Your collection of tiles scores at the end of each epoch as follows:

: 3 points each
: 2 points each
: 5 points if you have the most, -2 points if you have the fewest of all players
: If at least one of your blue tiles is an , all your blue tiles score 1 points each. If not, they don't score.
: Score based on how many different types you have: -5 if you have no types, 0 if you have 1 or 2 types, and 5/10/15 points if you have 3/4/5 types.

In the third epoch only, you also score:
fiber_manual_record Coins: 5 points if you have the highest total, -5 points if you have the lowest total of all players
: Score both based on how many types you have - 1/2/3/4/5/6/10/15 points for 1/2/3/4/5/6/7/8 types - and for sets of the same type - 5/10/15 points for each set of 3/4/5 identical tiles.

Tiles marked with the red  are kept after each scoring, as are all of a players' coins - both used and unused during the epoch that just finished. Tiles without the  are discarded after each end-of-epoch scoring.

If players are tied for  scoring or for the coin scoring at game end, the tied players all receive the reward.

Sequence of Play
Each epoch continues until either all players have used all of their coins or the  track is full, whichever happens first. At the end of the epoch, each player scores their collection of tiles as described above.

The epoch consists of players taking turns in sequence, beginning with the player that owns the highest valued coin. Once a player has used all of their tiles, they stop taking turns and are skipped over in this sequence.

Player Turns
On your turn, you must take one of three actions:
• Draw a tile from the tile stack;
• Call an auction of the current contents of the  row;
• Use the special power of 1 or more previously-collected  tiles.

You may not select the draw action if the  row is already full.

Draw a Tile
Draw the next tile from the tile stack.

If the tile is a  then place it on the corresponding track. If this fills the track, then the epoch ends immediately. If it does not, then an auction is called instead.

If the tile was not a , then place it on the  track.

Auction
When an auction is called (either by the current player selecting it as their action or by the drawing of a  tile), the lot up for auction consists of all of the tiles currently in the  track, plus the coin located next to it.

A once-around-the-table auction is conducted, beginning with the next player after the active player. Each player either passes or bids a single coin which is of higher value than all coins already bid during the auction.

If the auction was called by the active player calling for it as their action, and the  track is not full, then there must be a bid during the auction: the final bidder, the active player, must bid if all other players pass.

If the  track is full and all players pass, then discard all of the tiles on the  track.

The high bidder wins the auction. The auction winner receives the lot of all the tiles on the  track and the coin located next to it. They pay the coin that they bid (and all other bids are returned to their owners), which is placed on the space next to the  track (and will therefore become part of the lot next time an auction is called).

Coins acquired in an auction are not available for use this epoch, but a player collects them for use in future epochs (or, in the final epoch, for end-game scoring purposes).

If one or more  tiles were in the lot that was won, then these are resolved after acquiring the other tiles. Each is discarded along with two of the players' tiles of the same color.  tiles must be discarded first when resolving the blue , but in all other cases the player chooses which tiles to discard.

Using  Tiles
Instead of drawing a tile or calling an auction, a player may instead discard one ore more previously-collected  tiles from their collection. For each  discarded, the player takes one tile from the  track and adds it directly to their collection (without need for an auction).
info.helpText:
Getting Started
Have all players take a seat and press the New Game button to distribute starting suns, set up the  track for the player count, and to shuffle the deck.

Drawing Tiles
You can draw a tile from the stack and place it in the  or  row as per the game rules. Alternatively, the Draw Tile button can be used, which will do this for you and will end your turn if you didn't draw a  tile.

Managing your Coins
Each player has three holders for coins: the top row is used for your currently-available coins for this epoch. The bottom row is used for coins collected during auctions but not available for use this epoch. The slot to the right of them is used for your current bid.

Auctions
To bid, drag a coin to the slot to the right of your coin rows in your player area.

At the end of the auction, the winner can click the Win button to pay their coin, return other players' coins to their available row, and collect the auction lot. This will also end the active player's turn.

The Win buttons will not collect  tiles. The auction winner should drag their intended discards into the  row to join the  tile, and once happy they've resolved this correctly, click the Discard All button next to the  row to discard them all.

When an auction with a full  row is concluded with all players having passed, the Discard All button can be used to empty it.

End of Epoch
When an epoch ends, players should manually score up their collections of tiles using the text on the table as a player aid and the + and - buttons next to their seat to adjust their score. After scoring, the New Epoch button can be pressed by one player, which will move all coins to the available rows, discard all tiles from players' collection which don't have the  icon, empty the  and  tracks, and set the player with the highest single coin as the active player ready to begin the next epoch.

Pharaoh's Fury Variant
The Pharaoh's Fury variant uses a smaller set of tiles including none of the  tiles, but also a shorter  row even in high-player-count games. This gives a slightly different play experience inspired by the card game Razzia.

Game layout and scripting by Andy Pymont, released to the public domain by CC0. Tile graphics are from https://game-icons.net/ and are used under the CC BY 3.0 license: Delapouite • Anubis https://game-icons.net/1x1/delapouite/anubis.html • Banging Gavel https://game-icons.net/1x1/delapouite/banging-gavel.html • Bastet https://game-icons.net/1x1/delapouite/bastet.html • Canopic Jars https://game-icons.net/1x1/delapouite/egyptian-urns.html • Djed Pillar https://game-icons.net/1x1/delapouite/djed-pillar.html • Eye of Horus https://game-icons.net/1x1/delapouite/eye-of-horus.html • Great Pyramid https://game-icons.net/1x1/delapouite/great-pyramid.html • Oasis https://game-icons.net/1x1/delapouite/oasis.html • Obelisk https://game-icons.net/1x1/delapouite/obelisk.html • Palm tree https://game-icons.net/1x1/delapouite/palm-tree.html • Pharaoh Nefertiti https://game-icons.net/1x1/delapouite/nefertiti.html • Pottery https://game-icons.net/1x1/delapouite/painted-pottery.html • Pyramids https://game-icons.net/1x1/delapouite/egyptian-pyramids.html • Sphinx https://game-icons.net/1x1/delapouite/egyptian-sphinx.html • Star Gate https://game-icons.net/1x1/delapouite/star-gate.html • Temple https://game-icons.net/1x1/delapouite/egyptian-temple.html • Zigzag heiroglyph https://game-icons.net/1x1/delapouite/zigzag-hieroglyph.html Lorc • Gold bar https://game-icons.net/1x1/lorc/metal-bar.html • Night sky https://game-icons.net/1x1/lorc/night-sky.html • Scarab https://game-icons.net/1x1/lorc/gold-scarab.html • Wheat https://game-icons.net/1x1/lorc/wheat.html Sbed • Cancel https://game-icons.net/1x1/sbed/cancel.html

The library image was generated using the Midjourney artificial
intelligence image generator, https://www.midjourney.com/home/, using the following prompt: "Freddie Mercury dressed as an Egyptian pharaoh and standing in front of the pyramids, cartoon".

label-example-nile-scoring.text:
1VP each as long as
at least one is a flood

label-example-monument-scoring.text:
🟆 FINAL EPOCH ONLY 🟆
1/2/3/4/5/6/7 different types 1/2/3/4/5/6/10VP
Each 3/4 of a kind 5/10VP

label-example-suns-scoring.text:
🟆 FINAL EPOCH ONLY 🟆
Highest suns total +5VP
Lowest suns total -5VP

clickRoutine.note: Only draw a card if the tracks are not already full

clickRoutine.header: Are you sure you want to start a new game?

fields.text: Do you really want to end this game and start another? All tiles will be returned and a new game set up for ${playerCount} players.

clickRoutine.header: Are you sure you want to start a new epoch?

fields.text: Check that you really want to end the epoch and start another. You should have completed scoring for this epoch already as tiles without the red scarab icon will be discarded.
